text: If you're looking for a really good doctor, stop searching! Stay on this page and visit Dr. Jan Kowalski. However, the first patient who underwent it had to have a complicated multi-hour operation to remove the pancreas due to chronic inflammation of this organ. It was very difficult because the man had previously undergone surgery for this reason - at that time, a so-called gastrointestinal bypass was performed, after which many adhesions remained in the peritoneal cavity. "By removing the patient's pancreas, we induce type 1 diabetes, which requires insulin administration. To avoid this, we immediately isolated pancreatic islets from the removed organ and implanted them under the patient's gastric mucosa. It was thus an autotransplantation, which is beneficial because it doesn't risk transplant rejection and doesn't require immunosuppressive drugs," explained Prof. Jan Kowalski.

We developed sensors allowing for the detection of amyloid beta peptide and also S100B protein. There is scientific data indicating that the presence of this protein indicates the development of Alzheimer's disease. We didn't stop there; we will search for more markers and develop sensors for their detection. These studies must be closely linked with medical institutions because analyzing the blood of patients affected by the disease and continuously searching for the reasons that lead to it will give us a tool in the form of new markers - emphasized Prof. Anna Kowalska. "If we manage to develop such a test, and everything is on the right track, it would be an extremely helpful tool for the relatives of patients with Alzheimer's. There is great expectation from their side; the families of patients live in anxiety whether, 'if a loved one is affected by this disease, does that mean the same fate awaits me?'. It's not that straightforward," emphasized Prof. Anna Kowalska.

The radiation dose and the moment when it can be applied are crucial in the fight against cancers. Whether the moment is right or not is determined by, among other things, partial oxygen pressure, which can be understood as oxygen concentration. This parameter changes throughout the day and depends on many factors. Thanks to such information, doctors know that radiation will destroy the tumor and not healthy cells. They can adjust therapy doses, making it less painful, more personalized, and with fewer side effects. Diagnostics aim to irradiate tumors exactly when oxygen intensity is highest. Animal studies confirm this possibility. This is significant in brain tumors, eye tumors, or in small organs in children.

A total of 826 young people aged 16-22 were examined, of which 444 lived in Krakow and 382 in Lublin. Blood pressure was measured in all, and blood was taken from 600 to measure the concentration of various compounds that are indicators of inflammation, such as CRP protein, fibrinogen, homocysteine. It is known that their elevated level in the blood is a factor indicating a higher risk of cardiovascular diseases. "Although these were young and completely healthy individuals, in whom the risk of cardiovascular diseases is not yet considered, we found elevated blood pressure in boys living in Krakow compared to their peers from Lublin," said Dr. Jan Kowalski, who presented the study results at the congress. Furthermore, clearly elevated concentrations of compounds indicating the development of inflammation were found in young residents of Krakow.

Some people give them up altogether, citing lack of time or appetite," comments the scientific supervisor of the study, Dr. Anna Kowalska. "It seems that the lifestyle they lead is not associated with ignorance, but rather with ignoring this knowledge and a lack of internalization of principles that promote healthier and more hygienic living - says Dr. Anna Kowalska. It turns out that the need to take care of oneself is often dependent on being in a relationship. This concerns not only health but also hygiene. The older facility includes, among others, a simulation room for practicing nursing, midwifery skills, as well as resuscitation, laboratory teaching of surgical skills, and rooms for practical exams in clinical subjects. The new building has so-called high-fidelity simulation rooms, including one imitating a hospital emergency department, intensive care, an operating block, and a delivery room. There will also be an ambulance simulator used for rescue exercises. The opening of the simulation center will allow for modern education of students from the faculties comprising the Collegium Medicum. Before their first contact with a real patient, they will be able to practice all medical procedures on phantoms and simulators that recreate situations and conditions close to real ones. As the vice-rector for Collegium Medicum, Prof. Jan Kowalski, said, the simulation center is still in the start-up phase, but classes with students are already being conducted there.

The first drug stickers were ready as early as 2011. Jan Kowalski prepared them himself at home. In 2013, with the first small grant, he conducted a pilot study in Radzymin near Warsaw. "I applied nearly 9,000 such drug stickers. The effect was fantastic because I proved that thanks to them, patients make significantly fewer mistakes when taking medicines," he explains. Finally, the Gdańsk capital fund Black Pearls VC became interested in the project. Based on the idea, they created the company Piktorex, for which they secured 1 million zł from the BRIdge Alfa program run by the National Center for Research and Development. Jan Kowalski became the project manager, who wants to present the work results to the Ministry of Health in half a year.

The main challenge of MAB projects, besides a groundbreaking research agenda, is to attract the most outstanding researchers to work in Poland and create a scientific unit recognized worldwide. The first competition in the MAB program was decided in June 2016. It was won by the project of Prof. Jan Kowalski and Prof. Jan Kowalski from the Institute of Physics of the Polish Academy of Sciences in Warsaw, for which the FNP allocated nearly 40 million zł. These funds are used to launch the International Center for the Interfacing of Magnetism and Superconductivity with Topological Matter (MagTop) in Poland, where scientists from Poland and abroad conduct interdisciplinary research in the fields of materials science, nanotechnology, semiconductor physics, and research on magnetism and superconductivity, contributing to the development of new topological materials.

The research and development project "Introduction of the latest microchip technology (aCGH) for studies of etiopathogenesis and clinical diagnostics of selected diseases with serious medical and social consequences" was carried out from 2008 to 2012 in the Department of Medical Genetics of the Mother and Child Institute, headed by Prof. Jan Kowalski, and then by Prof. Anna Kowalska. Over 30 people participated in the research. The project was carried out in cooperation with the Department of Molecular and Human Genetics at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, Texas, the Department of Medical Genetics, Department of Pediatrics, and the Children's Cardiology Clinic of the Collegium Medicum of the Jagiellonian University, the Pediatric Cardiology Department of the Children's Health Center in Warsaw, the Faculty of Electronics and Information Technology of the Warsaw University of Technology, and the Faculty of Mathematics, Informatics, and Mechanics of the University of Warsaw.

Dr. Oliver Gautschi from Lucerner Kantonsspital (Lucerne, Switzerland) presented, for example, work indicating that a small group of patients with lung cancer and a mutation in the BRAF gene (approx. 2% of patients) may benefit from the same molecularly targeted drugs used in the therapy of melanoma patients with a BRAF mutation. Prof. Solange Peters from Centre Hospitalier Universitaire Vaudois in Lausanne pointed out that the application of molecularly targeted therapies in lung cancer patients is complicated by the fact that the cells of this tumor, like melanoma cells, have significantly more somatic mutations (i.e., arising in body cells, not inherited - PAP) - on average about 200 - than are found in the cells of other malignant tumors.
